messages.content:
DEPRECATED: The legacy builder is deprecated and will be removed in a future release.
            Install the buildx component to build images with BuildKit:
            https://docs.docker.com/go/buildx/

Cannot connect to the Docker daemon at unix:///var/run/docker.sock. Is the docker daemon running?
docker: Cannot connect to the Docker daemon at unix:///var/run/docker.sock. Is the docker daemon running?.
See 'docker run --help'.

The message you received indicates that the Docker daemon is not running or that the current user does not have permission to access it. To resolve this issue, you can try the following steps:

1. Check if the Docker daemon is running by running the following command in the terminal:

   ```
   sudo systemctl status docker
   ```

   If the output shows that the Docker service is not running, you can start it using the following command:

   ```
   sudo systemctl start docker
   ```

2. If you are still unable to connect to the Docker daemon, you may need to add your user to the `docker` group by running the following command:

   ```
   sudo usermod -aG docker your_username
   ```

   After running this command, you will need to log out and back in for the changes to take effect.

Once the Docker daemon is running and your user has permission to access it, you should be able to run Docker commands without any issues.

On macOS, you can check if the Docker daemon is running by opening the Docker Desktop application. If the Docker daemon is not running, you can start it from the Docker Desktop application.

If you're still unable to connect to the Docker daemon, you can try restarting Docker Desktop or restarting your computer. If the issue persists, you can try resetting the Docker Desktop installation by clicking on "Docker Desktop" in the menu bar and selecting "Troubleshoot" > "Reset to factory defaults".

Additionally, you can also check if the Docker daemon is running by running the following command in the terminal:

```
docker info
```

If you see a message that says "Cannot connect to the Docker daemon", it means that the Docker daemon is not running. You can start the Docker daemon by running the following command:

```
open /Applications/Docker.app
```

This should open the Docker Desktop application and start the Docker daemon. After the Docker daemon is running, you should be able to run Docker commands without any issues.

./setup.sh: line 15: .env: Permission denied
./setup.sh: line 18: .env.docker: Permission denied
DEPRECATED: The legacy builder is deprecated and will be removed in a future release.
            Install the buildx component to build images with BuildKit:
            https://docs.docker.com/go/buildx/

Cannot connect to the Docker daemon at unix:///var/run/docker.sock. Is the docker daemon running?
docker: Cannot connect to the Docker daemon at unix:///var/run/docker.sock. Is the docker daemon running?.
See 'docker run --help'.

The error message suggests that the script `setup.sh` does not have the necessary permissions to access the `.env` and `.env.docker` files. 

You can try granting executable permission to the `setup.sh` script by running the following command:

```
chmod +x setup.sh
```

This will give the script executable permission and allow it to access the necessary files.

Regarding the Docker daemon error, it seems like the Docker daemon is not running or the current user does not have permission to access it. You can try the steps mentioned in my previous response to start the Docker daemon and add your user to the `docker` group.

Once the Docker daemon is running and your user has permission to access it, you should be able to run the `setup.sh` script and Docker commands without any issues.
Cannot connect to the Docker daemon at unix:///var/run/docker.sock. Is the docker daemon running?

The error message "Cannot connect to the Docker daemon at unix:///var/run/docker.sock. Is the docker daemon running?" usually indicates that the Docker daemon is not running or that the current user does not have permission to access it.

To check if the Docker daemon is running, you can run the following command in your terminal:

```
sudo systemctl status docker
```

If the output shows that the Docker service is not running, you can start it using the following command:

```
sudo systemctl start docker
```

If you're still unable to connect to the Docker daemon, you may need to add your user to the `docker` group by running the following command:

```
sudo usermod -aG docker your_username
```

After running this command, you will need to log out and back in for the changes to take effect.

Once the Docker daemon is running and your user has permission to access it, you should be able to run Docker commands without any issues.
it's on my Mac what's the commands

On macOS, you can check if the Docker daemon is running by opening the Docker Desktop application. If the Docker daemon is not running, you can start it from the Docker Desktop application.

If you prefer to use the command line, you can check the status of the Docker service by running the following command in your terminal:

```
sudo launchctl list | grep docker
```

If the output shows that the Docker service is not running, you can start it using the following command:

```
sudo launchctl start com.docker.service
```

If you're still unable to connect to the Docker daemon, you may need to add your user to the `docker` group by running the following command:

```
sudo usermod -aG docker your_username
```

After running this command, you will need to log out and back in for the changes to take effect.

Once the Docker daemon is running and your user has permission to access it, you should be able to run Docker commands without any issues.
